segments.en: Middle Discourses 23
The Ant-Hill
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā kumārakassapo andhavane viharati.
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Kassapa the Prince was staying in the Dark Forest.

segments.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ andhavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāyasmā kumārakassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā āyasmantaṃ kumārakassapaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Dark Forest, went up to Kassapa the Prince, stood to one side, and said:

segments.pli: “Bhikkhu bhikkhu, ayaṃ vammiko rattiṃ dhūmāyati, divā pajjalati.
segments.en: “Monk, monk! This ant-hill fumes by night and flames by day.
The brahmin said,
‘Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’

segments.pli: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṃ ādāya addasa laṅgiṃ
segments.en: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a bar:
‘A bar, sir!’
The brahmin said,
‘Throw out the bar!
Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’

segments.pli: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṃ ādāya addasa uddhumāyikaṃ.
segments.en: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a bullfrog:
‘A bullfrog, sir!’
The brahmin said,
‘Throw out the bullfrog!
Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’

segments.pli: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṃ ādāya addasa dvidhāpathaṃ.
segments.en: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a forked path:
‘A forked path, sir!’
The brahmin said,
‘Throw out the forked path!
Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’

segments.pli: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṃ ādāya addasa caṅgavāraṃ.
segments.en: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a box:
‘A box, sir!’
The brahmin said,
‘Throw out the box!
Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’

segments.pli: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṃ ādāya addasa kummaṃ.
segments.en: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a tortoise:
‘A tortoise, sir!’
The brahmin said,
‘Throw out the tortoise!
Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’

segments.pli: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṃ ādāya addasa asisūnaṃ.
segments.en: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw an axe and block:
‘An axe and block, sir!’
The brahmin said,
‘Throw out the axe and block!
Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’

segments.pli: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṃ ādāya addasa maṃsapesiṃ.
segments.en: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a lump of meat:
‘A lump of meat, sir!’
The brahmin said,
‘Throw out the lump of meat!
Take up the sword and dig, O sage!’

segments.pli: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṃ ādāya addasa nāgaṃ.
segments.en: Taking up the sword and digging, the sage saw a dragon:
‘A dragon, sir!’
The brahmin said,

segments.pli: ‘tiṭṭhatu nāgo, mā nāgaṃ ghaṭṭesi; namo karohi nāgassā’ti.
segments.en: ‘Leave the dragon! Do not disturb the dragon! Worship the dragon!’

segments.pli: Ime kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, pañhe bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyāsi, yathā ca te bhagavā byākaroti tathā naṃ dhāreyyāsi.
segments.en: Mendicant, go to the Buddha and ask him about this riddle. You should remember it in line with his answer.

segments.pli: Nāhaṃ taṃ, bhikkhu, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yo imesaṃ pañhānaṃ veyyākaraṇena cittaṃ ārādheyya aññatra tathāgatena vā, tathāgatasāvakena vā, ito vā pana sutvā”ti—
segments.en: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to this riddle except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.”
That is what that deity said
before vanishing right there.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā kumārakassapo tassā rattiyā accayena yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā kumārakassapo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then, when the night had passed, Kassapa the Prince went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he asked:

segments.pli: “imaṃ, bhante, rattiṃ aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ andhavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhante, sā devatā maṃ etadavoca:
‘bhikkhu bhikkhu, ayaṃ vammiko rattiṃ dhūmāyati, divā pajjalati.

Ko nu kho, bhante, vammiko, kā rattiṃ dhūmāyanā, kā divā pajjalanā, ko brāhmaṇo, ko sumedho, kiṃ satthaṃ, kiṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ, kā laṅgī, kā uddhumāyikā, ko dvidhāpatho, kiṃ caṅgavāraṃ, ko kummo, kā asisūnā, kā maṃsapesi, ko nāgo”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, what is the ant-hill? What is the fuming by night and flaming by day? Who is the brahmin, and who the sage? What are the sword, the digging, the bar, the bullfrog, the forked path, the box, the tortoise, the axe and block, and the lump of meat? And what is the dragon?”

segments.pli: “‘Vammiko’ti kho, bhikkhu, imassetaṃ cātumahābhūtikassa kāyassa adhivacanaṃ, mātāpettikasambhavassa odanakummāsūpacayassa aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammassa. (1)
segments.en: “Mendicant, ‘ant-hill’ is a term for this body made up of the four primary elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.

segments.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, divā kammante ārabbha rattiṃ anuvitakketi anuvicāreti—
segments.en: Thinking and considering all night about what you did during the day—
this is the fuming at night.

segments.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, rattiṃ anuvitakketvā anuvicāretvā divā kammante payojeti kāyena vācāya ‘manasā’—
segments.en: The work you apply yourself to during the day by body, speech, and mind after thinking about it all night—
this is the flaming by day.

segments.pli: ‘Brāhmaṇo’ti kho, bhikkhu, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
segments.en: ‘Brahmin’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
‘Sage’ is a term for the trainee mendicant.
‘Sword’ is a term for noble wisdom.
‘Digging’ is a term for being energetic.
‘Bar’ is a term for ignorance.
‘Throw out the bar’ means ‘give up ignorance,

segments.pli: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṃ ādāyāti ayametassa attho. (8)
segments.en: take up the sword, sage, and dig.’
‘Bullfrog’ is a term for anger and distress.
‘Throw out the bullfrog’ means ‘give up anger and distress’ …

segments.pli: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṃ ādāyāti ayametassa attho. (9)

segments.en: ‘A forked path’ is a term for doubt.
‘Throw out the forked path’ means ‘give up doubt’ …

segments.pli: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṃ ādāyāti ayametassa attho. (10)
‘Caṅgavāran’ti kho, bhikkhu, pañcannetaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ adhivacanaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: ‘Box’ is a term for the five hindrances, that is:
the hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
‘Throw out the box’ means ‘give up the five hindrances’ …

segments.pli: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṃ ādāyāti ayametassa attho. (11)
‘Kummo’ti kho, bhikkhu, pañcannetaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ adhivacanaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: ‘Tortoise’ is a term for the five grasping aggregates, that is:
form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
‘Throw out the tortoise’ means ‘give up the five grasping aggregates’ …

segments.pli: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṃ ādāyāti ayametassa attho. (12)

segments.en: ‘Axe and block’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

segments.pli: cakkhuviññeyyānaṃ rūpānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ,
segments.en: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
Sounds known by the ear …
Smells known by the nose …
Tastes known by the tongue …

segments.pli: kāyaviññeyyānaṃ phoṭṭhabbānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ piyarūpānaṃ kāmūpasaṃhitānaṃ rajanīyānaṃ.
segments.en: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
‘Throw out the axe and block’ means ‘give up the five kinds of sensual stimulation’ …

segments.pli: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṃ ādāyāti ayametassa attho. (13)

segments.en: ‘Lump of meat’ is a term for desire with relishing.
‘Throw out the lump of meat’ means ‘give up desire with relishing’ …

segments.pli: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṃ ādāyāti ayametassa attho. (14)

segments.en: ‘Dragon’ is a term for a mendicant who has ended the defilements.

segments.pli: Tiṭṭhatu nāgo, mā nāgaṃ ghaṭṭesi; namo karohi nāgassāti ayametassa attho”ti. (15)
segments.en: This is the meaning of: ‘Leave the dragon! Do not disturb the dragon! Worship the dragon.’”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamano āyasmā kumārakassapo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
segments.en: Satisfied, Venerable Kassapa the Prince was happy with what the Buddha said.

suttaplex.blurb: In a curious discourse laden with evocative imagery, a deity presents a riddle to a mendicant, who seeks an answer from the Buddha.
